{{Other people|John Wilson}} {{Infobox Politician (general) |name = John Henry Wilson |image =John H. Wilson (vol. 2, 1921).jpg |order1 = 4th |office1 = Mayor of Honolulu|Mayor of City & County of Honolulu|Honolulu |term_start1 = 1920 |term_end1 = 1927 |predecessor1 = [[Joseph J. Fern]] |successor1 = [[Charles Arnold]] |order2 = 6th |office2 = Mayor of Honolulu|Mayor of City & County of Honolulu|Honolulu |term_start2 = 1929 |term_end2 = 1931 |predecessor2 = [[Charles Arnold]] |successor2 = [[George F. Wright]] |order3 = 10th |office3 = Mayor of Honolulu|Mayor of City & County of Honolulu|Honolulu |term_start3 = 1947 |term_end3 = 1955 |predecessor3 = [[Lester Petrie]] |successor3 = [[Neal Blaisdell]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1871|12|15|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Honolulu]], [[Kingdom of Hawaii]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1956|7|3|1871|12|15|mf=y}}[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/453161062.html?dids=453161062:453161062&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Jan+27%2C+1954&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Obituary+4+--+No+Title&pqatl=google] |death_place = Honolulu, [[Territory of Hawaii]] (now State of [[Hawaii]]) |other_names = Johnny |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] |spouse = [[Kini Kapahu|Ana Kuululani]] |partner = |relations = [[Charles Burnett Wilson (marshal)|C. B. Wilson]]
(father) |children = |residence = |alma_mater = [[Stanford University]] |known_for = Founder of the [[Democratic Party of Hawaii]] |occupation = [[Civil Engineer]] |nationality = [[Kingdom of Hawaii]], [[Republic of Hawaii]], [[United States]] |religion= [[Congregationalist]] |website= |allegiance=[[Kingdom of Hawaii]] |branch= [[Kingdom of Hawaii#Government in Exile|Royalist Insurgency]] |serviceyears= |rank= |unit= [[Maui]] detachment |battles=[[1895 Counter-Revolution in Hawaii|Uprising of 1895]] }} '''John Henry Wilson''' (December 15, 1871 – July 3, 1956), was a [[civil engineer]], [[insurgent]], co-founder of the [[Democratic Party of Hawaii]], and [[Mayor of Honolulu|Mayor]] of [[Honolulu, Hawaii]] three times: from 1920 to 1927, from 1929 to 1931, and from 1946 to 1954. ==Early years== Wilson was born in [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]] in 1871. His father was [[Charles B. Wilson]] (1850–1926), whose ethnic background was [[Scottish people|Scottish]] and [[Tahitians|Tahitian]]. C.B. Wilson was superintendent of the water works and fire chief under [[Kalākaua|King Kalākaua]], and was Marshal of the Kingdom under [[Liliuokalani|Queen Lili{{okina}}uokalani]].{{cite web|url=http://archives1.dags.hawaii.gov/gsdl/collect/governme/index/assoc/HASH0169/b46db112.dir/Wilson,%20Charles%20B.jpg |title=Wilson, Charles B. office record |work=state archives digital collections |publisher=state of Hawaii |accessdate=2010-01-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306202740/http://archives1.dags.hawaii.gov/gsdl/collect/governme/index/assoc/HASH0169/b46db112.dir/Wilson%2C%20Charles%20B.jpg |archivedate=2012-03-06 |df= }} His mother was three quarters of European descent and one quarter [[Native Hawaiians|Hawaiian]] Eveline M. "Kitty or Kittie" Townsend, granddaughter of Captain [[Henry Blanchard]] of the ship ''Thaddeus'' which had brought the first missionaries of the [[American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions]] to Hawaii in 1820. Wilson attended the Fort Street School and St. Alban's College. After graduating, he worked odd jobs on the West Coast, Hawaii, and Alaska. A construction job that he took in 1890 with [[Oahu Railway and Land Company|Oahu Railway & Land]] led him to pursue civil engineering as a career. With financial support from the Queen, he enrolled at [[Stanford University]] in 1891. However, lack of funds after the overthrow of the monarchy in 1893 forced him to leave Stanford in 1894. While on the [[Contiguous United States|mainland]] he was approached by revolutionaries looking for suppliers for the [[1895 Counter-Revolution in Hawaii]], and attempt to restore the monarchy. He took part in the [[Arms trafficking|smuggling of guns and ammunition]] to [[Maui]] as part of the arms buildup by rebel forces. After the failed revolution he spoke little about his role in fearing he would be arrested for treason. He admitted he smuggled guns and was of rank to participate in planning his mission. He planned to [[Landing operation|land a ship]] of insurgents from Maui to attack Honolulu, but was the mission was aborted after the revolution was exposed and martial law was activated. In 1896 he once again joined Oahu Railway & Land and worked on a survey for a carriage road over the [[Nuuanu Pali|Nu{{okina}}uanu Pali]]. Armed with this knowledge, he and fellow Stanford student Louis Whitehouse bid for and won the contract to build the road, completing the road in January 1898. ==Political career== Wilson served as roads engineer for both Maui and Honolulu counties. He was in a meeting on April 30, 1900 that organized the [[Democratic Party of Hawaii]]. He married [[hula]] practitioner [[Kini Kapahu]] on May 8, 1909. They moved to [[Molokaʻi]] and lived in the Pelekunu Valley before returning to Honolulu in 1919.{{cite book|first=Gillian S. |last=Holmes|editor1-last=Commire|editor1-first=Anne|title=Women in World History: A Biographical Encyclopedia|date=2002|publisher=Yorkin Publications|location=Waterford, Connecticut|isbn=0-7876-4074-3|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-2591309931.html|chapter=Wilson, Kini (1872–1962)|subscription=yes}} His first political campaign was for a seat in the Territorial Senate in 1918, which he lost. However, upon the death of Mayor [[Joseph J. Fern]] in 1920, Wilson was selected by the Board of Supervisors to succeed him. Wilson served three times as mayor, from 1920 to 1927, 1929 to 1931, and from 1946 to 1954, a total of 19 years. As mayor, Wilson oversaw the completion of [[Honolulu Hale]], which was completed in 1929 and consolidated the functions of the city's government. He also served on some territorial commissions, including coordinating the state holiday, [[Kamehameha Day]], until 1956.{{cite web |url= http://archives1.dags.hawaii.gov/gsdl/collect/governme/index/assoc/HASH019b/0e4d1cfe.dir/Wilson,%20John%20H.jpg |title= Wilson, John H. office record |work=state archives digital collections |publisher=state of Hawaii |accessdate=2010-01-05 }} Following World War II Wilson considered retirement he had been ''de facto'' leader of the Democratic Party of the original five founders only two remained. [[David Kawānanakoa]] died in 1908, [[John S. McGrew]] died in 1911, and [[Charles J. McCarthy]] died in 1929. [[Delbert E. Metzger]] was a [[Federal Judge]] and powerful Democrat but his judicial career reduced his participation in politics this left Wilson as leader. Wilson preferred to leave the party in good hands. An ambitious detective named [[John A. Burns]] emerged as a successor Wilson could pass the torch to. In his 80s, Wilson was once again a revolutionary as a key member of a [[nonviolent revolution]] called the [[Democratic Revolution of 1954 (Hawaii)|Democratic Revolution of 1954]] that brought his party to power. The early Democrats held a dislike toward [[Asian-American]]s as threats to Hawaiians and the social demographics of Hawaii. But unlike his colleagues, Wilson himself an early Democrat and part-Hawaiian, allowed passage of [[442nd Infantry Regiment (United States)|442nd]] veterans into the party, such as [[Daniel Inouye]] and [[Spark Matsunaga]]. He lived long enough to see the party that had overthrown the monarchy be dethroned themselves, and to some extent accomplishing what he failed in 1895. During this turbulent time Democrats were divided between [[right-wing]] "Walkouts" led by [[Ingram Stainback]] and the [[left-wing]] "Standpats" led by Burns, Wilson was a Standpat. A damaging letter written by Wilson criticizing non-Hawaii-born Democrats alluding to Stainback was considered the major factor in his loss to Republican [[Neal Blaisdell]]. During the late 1950s, Wilson advocated that the territorial government build a tunnel through the Ko{{okina}}olau Mountains from Honolulu to Kaneohe through Kalihi Valley. The territorial government, however, opted to build the tunnel through the Nu{{okina}}uanu Pali. The city eventually proceeded with plans to build a second set of tunnels through Kalihi Valley, which opened in 1961, five years after Wilson's death. The tunnels were named the John H. Wilson Tunnels in his honor. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |title= Johnny Wilson: first Hawaiian Democrat |author= Bob Krauss |publisher= University of Hawaii Press |year= 1994 |isbn= 978-0-8248-1577-6 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=mBYfPPI0XYYC }} ==External links== {{commons category}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20040911000648/http://www.ascehawaii.org/herit2001.html ASCE Hawaii] - describes Johnny Wilson's early achievements {{s-start}} {{succession box | before=[[Joseph J. Fern]] | title=[[Mayor of Honolulu]] | years=1920 - 1927| after=[[Charles Arnold]]}} {{succession box | before=[[Charles Arnold]] | title=[[Mayor of Honolulu]] | years=1929 - 1931| after=[[George F. Wright]]}} {{succession box | before=[[Lester Petrie]] | title=[[Mayor of Honolulu]] | years= 1947 - 1955| after=[[Neal Blaisdell]]}} {{s-end}} {{HonoluluMayors}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wilson, John Henry}} [[Category:1871 births]] [[Category:1956 deaths]] [[Category:Hawaii Democrats]] [[Category:Mayors of Honolulu]] [[Category:Native Hawaiian politicians]] [[Category:Native Hawaiian people]] [[Category:Hawaiian insurgents and supporters]] [[Category:ʻIolani School alumni]]

'''Julius Spearbraker''' was a member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]].
==Biography== Spearbraker was born on September 8, 1886 in [[Clintonville, Wisconsin]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z8NWAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA71&lpg=PA71&dq=Julius+Spearbraker%2BWisconsin&source=bl&ots=TbPI-2AXEF&sig=EooyDOUaIacaND5oe6aevmqe5hY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=sFe1UrL5FoX4yAHTMg&ved=0CFEQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Julius%20Spearbraker%2BWisconsin&f=false|title=Members of the Assembly|publisher=Wisconsin Blue Book|accessdate=2013-12-21}}</ref> He attended [[Marquette University]]. Spearbraker died in 1969.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/sparling-spellman.html#939.94.23|title=Spearbraker, Julius|publisher=Political Graveyard|accessdate=2013-12-21}}</ref>
==Career== Spearbraker was a member of the Assembly from 1939 to 1950. Previously, he had been Clerk of Clintonville from 1912 to 1934. Additionally, he was a delegate to the [[Republican National Convention]] in 1940 and 1944.
==References== {{reflist}}

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox person | | image = Kiran Rao on Day 3 of Lakme Fashion Week 2017.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Rao at the [[Lakme Fashion Week]] in 2017 | nationality = {{IND}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1973|11|07}}{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.oneindia.in/bollywood/news/2008/aamir-kiran-birthday-101108.html|title=Aamir surprises Kiran on birthday| work = Filmibeat.com | date = 10 November 2008 | accessdate = 2016-08-18}}{{cite news|last=Gupta|first=Pratim D. |title=She's the one!|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1101203/jsp/entertainment/story_13250072.jsp|accessdate=2 May 2011|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=3 December 2010|location=Calcutta, India}} | birth_place = [[Gadwal]], [[Telangana]], India | yearsactive = 2005–present | alma_mater= [[Sophia College for Women]]
[[Jamia Millia Islamia]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Aamir Khan]]|2005}} | children= 1 | occupation = Film producer, director, and screenwriter | relatives = [[Aditi Rao Hydari]] (cousin)}} '''Kiran Rao''' (born 7 November 1973) is an Indian film producer, screenwriter and director. She is the wife of Bollywood actor [[Aamir Khan]] and the cousin of actress [[Aditi Rao Hydari|Aditi Rao]] . ==Early life== Rao was born in [[Telangana]] on 7 November 1973.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} Her grandfather was [[J. Rameshwar Rao]], [[Raja of Wanaparthy]], [[Wanaparthy district]], [[Telangana state]]. In 1992, her parents decided to leave Kolkata so she moved to Mumbai. She graduated with a food sciences major from the [[Sophia College for Women]] in 1995. She attended the Social Communications Media course at the Sophia Polytechnic for two months, but then quit and left for [[Delhi]]. She got her Masters at [[AJK Mass Communication Research Center]] at [[Jamia Millia Islamia]], New Delhi.{{cite web|url=http://www.tehelka.com/story_main48.asp?filename=hub220111DEAR_MR.asp|title=Dear Mr. Subhash Ghai, my name is Kiran Rao|volume=8|issue=3|date=22 January 2011|work=Tehelka Magazine}} Actress [[Aditi Rao Hydari]] is Rao's first cousin. ==Career== Rao started her career as an assistant director in the [[epic film]] ''[[Lagaan]]'' directed by [[Ashutosh Gowariker]], whom she also assisted later on ''[[Swades|Swades: We, the People]]''. ''[[Lagaan]]'' was nominated for [[74th Academy Awards]] in the foreign language film category. [[Aamir Khan]] produced and starred in the same film. Before ''Lagaan'', she has also done minute role of supporting actress in ''[[Dil Chahta Hai]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.pinkvilla.com/entertainment/discussion/little-known-bollywood-debut-kiran-rao-dil-chahta-hai |title=The little known Bollywood debut of Kiran Rao in Dil Chahta Hai |publisher=Pinkvilla |accessdate=8 August 2012}} She also worked as second assistant director with [[Academy Award]] nominated director [[Mira Nair]] on the indie hit ''[[Monsoon Wedding]]''.[http://entertainment.in.msn.com/bollywoodthisdecade/coupleofthedecade/gallery.aspx?cp-documentid=3397575&page=2 Kiran Rao] She scripted and directed the film ''[[Dhobi Ghat (film)|Dhobi Ghat]]'', which was released in January 2011 under [[Aamir Khan Productions]].{{cite news|title=Aamir is a dream producer: Kiran Rao|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/news-interviews/Aamir-is-a-dream-producer-Kiran-Rao/articleshow/7332065.cms|work=The Times of India|accessdate=21 January 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.urblife.com/the-fame/aamir-khan-and-kiran-rao-talk-dhobi-ghat|title=India's Aamir Khan and Kiran Rao Talk Dhobi Ghat, Art, Love and Career|publisher=UrbLife.com|date=2 February 2011}} She has started writing her next film which will have roots in Kolkata. Kiran Rao was made the chairperson of the Mumbai Film Festival - MAMI in 2015.{{Cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/hope-to-make-space-for-indie-film-distribution-at-mami-kiran-rao/|title=Hope to make space for indie film distribution at MAMI: Kiran Rao|date=2015-06-30|newspaper=The Indian Express|access-date=2016-12-19}} She also sang a [[Marathi language|Marathi]] song 'Toofan Aala' Satyamev Jayate Water Cup Anthem https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PpZ1Q-KjUek ==Personal life== [[File:Aamir Khan & Kiran Rao promote Paani Foundation on the sets- of Chal Hawa Yeu Dya (5).jpg|thumb|Aamir Khan & Kiran Rao promote Paani Foundation on the sets of [[Marathi language|Marathi]] program [[Chala Hawa Yeu Dya]] in 2017.]] Rao married actor [[Aamir Khan]] in December 2005, after Khan divorced his first wife Reena Dutta in 2002. They met on the sets of ''[[Lagaan]]''. Rao was one of the film's assistant directors. They now live in [[Bandra]], a Mumbai suburb.{{cite web|url=http://www.expressindia.com/fullstory.php?newsid=60745 |title=Grand reception for Aamir Khan-Kiran Rao wedding |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070222235106/http://www.expressindia.com/fullstory.php?newsid=60745 |archivedate=22 February 2007 |df= }} The couple have a son, Azad Rao Khan (born on 5 December 2011), who has been named after Abdul Kalam Azad.{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Tabloid/Baby-boy-for-Aamir-Khan-Kiran-Rao/Article1-778024.aspx |title=Baby boy for Aamir Khan, Kiran Rao |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111206035418/http://www.hindustantimes.com/entertainment/tabloid/baby-boy-for-aamir-khan-kiran-rao/article1-778024.aspx |archivedate= 6 December 2011 |df= }} She is an Atheist.{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-08-14/news-interviews/41376061_1_aamir-khan-kiran-rao-motherhood | work=The Times Of India | title=Aamir made me open to different points of view: Kiran Rao - The Times of India}} Rao has been a vegan, and she has influenced her husband, Aamir Khan, to turn vegan as well. After discussing the issue, both of them decided to turn to vegan, and although Rao had been taking chicken and cigarettes during her non-veg days, she started taking it intensively following the discussion and agreement with her husband.{{cite news|url=http://www.mumbaimirror.com/entertainment/bollywood/Aamir-goes-the-non-vegan-way/articleshow/46522429.cms|title=AAMIR GOES THE VEGAN WAY!|work=Mumbai Mirror|date=11 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.in/2015/03/11/aamir-khan-vegan-masterch_n_6848652.html|title=Recently Turned Vegan Aamir Khan To Judge 'MasterChef India 4' Finale?|agency=IANS|work=The Huffington Post|date=15 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/aamir-khan-quits-non-vegetarian-food-turns-vegan/|title=Aamir Khan quits non-vegetarian food, turns vegan|agency=Express News Service|work=The Indian Express|date=11 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015}} Rao's paternal and Hydari’s maternal grandfather, [[J. Rameshwar Rao]], was the [[Raja of Wanaparthy]], a large estate under the [[Nizam of Hyderabad]]. Wanaparthy is a district of [[Telangana]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.andhraheadlines.com/news/movies/153873/aamirs-wife-kiran-has-roots-in-Thailand|title=Aamir's wife Kiran has roots in Thailand|accessdate=2015-11-26}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/151126/nation-current-affairs/article/kiran-aditi-rao%E2%80%99s-first-cousin-has-telangana-link|title=Kiran, Aditi Rao’s first cousin, has Telangana link|accessdate=2015-11-26|publisher=Deccan Chronicle}} ==Filmography== ===Director=== *''[[Dhobi Ghat (film)|Dhobi Ghat]]'' (''Mumbai Diaries''){{cite web|url=http://www.mid-day.com/entertainment/2009/feb/230209-Dhobi-Ghaat-Kiran-Rao-local-trains-railway-station-Mumbai-terror-attack-Pratiek-Babbar.htm |title=Aamir Khan's wife Kiran Rao's directorial debut, Dhobi Ghaat's shoot stuck|date=2009-02-23|work=Mid Day|first=Sonal|last=Chawla|accessdate=2016-08-18}} (2011) ===Assistant director=== *''[[Lagaan|Lagaan: Once Upon A Time in India]]'' (2001) *''[[Monsoon Wedding]]'' (2001) *''[[Saathiya (film)|Saathiya]]'' (2002) *''[[Swades|Swades: We, the People]]'' (2004) ===Producer=== *''[[Jaane Tu... {{Infobox writer | name = Lillian Resler Keister Harford | embed = | honorific_prefix = | honorific_suffix = | image = LILLIE RESLER KEISTER A woman of the century (page 440 crop).jpg | image_size = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = A woman of the century | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = Lillian Resler | birth_date = May 15, 1851 | birth_place = [[Mount Pleasant, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | death_date = 1935 | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = church organizer, editor, author | language = | residence = | nationality = American | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[Otterbein University]] | period = | genre = religious | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''History of the Women's Missionary Association of the United Brethren in Christ'' | spouse = {{marriage|George Keister|1875|1880|reason=died}}
{{marriage|William P. Harford|1893|1910|reason=died}} | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Lillian Resler Keister Harford'''{{efn|Archives of the Susquehanna Conference of the United Methodist Church spells her maiden name as "Ressler".{{cite web |title=Pennsylvania Conference UB Pastors |url=https://www.lycoming.edu/umarch/ub_pastors/k.htm |publisher=Lycoming College |accessdate=1 November 2018}}}}{{efn|Fire Underwriters' Association of the Northwest (1911) spells her married name as "Kiester".{{sfn|Fire Underwriters' Association of the Northwest|1911|p=184}}}} (May 15, 1851 – 1935) was an American church organizer, editor, and author. She was active worker in the Woman's Missionary Association of her church, the [[Church of the United Brethren in Christ|United Brethren in Christ]], and delivered lectures for the Women's Missionary Society. In 1880, she was one of the two delegates sent by the Association to the World's Missionary Conference in [[London]], England.{{sfn|Logan|1912|p=521}} She became the longest-serving president of the Association.{{sfn|Harford|Bell|1921|p=23}}{{cite web |last1=Kajue |first1=Hannah |title=Brief History of Harford |url=http://www.harfordexpupils.co.uk/briefhistoryofharford.html |website=www.harfordexpupils.co.uk |accessdate=1 November 2018}} ==Early years and education== Lillian ("Lillie"{{efn|Princeton Theological Seminary gives her nickname as "Lizzie".}}) A. Resler was born in [[Mount Pleasant, Pennsylvania]], May 15, 1851. She was the first of seven children born to Rev. and Mrs. Jacob B. Resler. A brother was named John I.L. Ressler. Rev. Resler (d. 1891) was minister of the United Brethren in Christ church of that city.{{sfn|Rankin|Good|1858|p=4}} He, with only a small salary, moved to [[Westerville, Ohio]], to give his children the benefit of [[Otterbein University]], as soon as Keister was ready to enter, which was in 1866. She was graduated with the class of 1872.{{sfn|Willard|Livermore|1893|p=430}}{{sfn|Otterbein College|1892|p=89}} ==Career== After completing her education, she became a school teacher.{{sfn|Willard|Livermore|1893|p=430}} On August 19, 1875, at Westerville,{{cite web |author=Princeton Theological Seminary |title=Necrological reports and annual proceedings of the Alumni Association ... : 1875-1932 |url=https://archive.org/stream/necrologicalrepo02prin#page/101/mode/1up |publisher=C.S. Robinson |accessdate=1 November 2018 |location=Princeton, New Jersey |pages=101–02 |date=1891|edition=Public domain}} she married Rev. George Keister (b. 1847), professor of Hebrew and Church History in [[United Theological Seminary]], [[Dayton, Ohio]], from 1875. They had no children. The early death, in August 1880,{{sfn|Bonebrake Theological Seminary|1913|p=44}} of her husband opened the way to her broader usefulness in church work. The church of her choice, the United Brethren in Christ, organized the Woman's Missionary Association in 1875, of which she was corresponding secretary for the first year. The work of the society grew and, in 1881, it called for the full time of one woman as its corresponding secretary and to establish and edit its organ, the ''Woman's Evangel''. Keister was the available woman well-qualified for the responsible position. She was unanimously elected, holding the position in 1875-76 and 1881-1893.{{sfn|Frey|2007|p=74}} Besides the work on the paper, much of her time was spent giving public addresses.{{sfn|Willard|Livermore|1893|p=430}} Keister traveled a lot. One year, she traveled in association work over {{convert|12000|miles}} in the United States. Twice, she went on short trips abroad, first in 1884, when the illness of her sister studying in Germany called her there, and again in 1888, when she was one of two delegates sent by the Woman's Missionary Association to the World's Missionary Conference in London.{{sfn|Willard|Livermore|1893|p=431}} ==Later years== {{multiple image |direction = vertical |align = right |width = 100 |image1 = William P. Harford.png |caption1 = William Harford |image2 = Lillian Resler Harford.png |caption2 = Lillian Harford }} On June 14, 1893, she married William P. Harford (1834-1910).{{sfn|Fire Underwriters' Association of the Northwest|1911|p=184}} Keister served as President of the Omaha Woman's Club, [[Omaha, Nebraska]].{{sfn|Rhinehart|1909|p=27}} Between 1905 and 1927, she was president of the Woman's Missionary Association. From 1927 till her death, she served as the Association's honorary president.{{sfn|Frey|2007|p=74}} In 1921, with Alice Estella Bell, she published ''History of the Women's Missionary Association of the United Brethren in Christ''.{{sfn|Harford|Bell|1921|p=1}} ==Death and legacy== Keister died in 1935.{{sfn|Frey|2007|p=74}} The dedication and renaming of the First United Brethren Church of Omaha, Nebraska, at Nineteenth and Lothrop Streets, occurred December 5, 1909, the new name being "The Lillian Resler Harford Memorial United Brethren Church of Omaha".{{sfn|Rhinehart|1909|p=18}} The Harford School for Girls (HSG), [[Moyamba, Sierra Leone]] is named in her honor. ==Selected works== * ''History of the Women's Missionary Association of the United Brethren in Christ'', 1921 ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Attribution=== * {{Source-attribution| {{cite book|ref=harv|author=Bonebrake Theological Seminary|title=Annual {{third-party|date=August 2018}} {{lead too short|date=August 2018}} '''Lorie Line''' (born 1958) is a classically trained [[pianist]], [[composer]], and performer from [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]].
== Life and career == Line grew up in [[Reno, Nevada]] and has played the piano since she was five years old. As a young musician, she won several state piano competitions annually.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lorieline.com/about.php|title=Lorie Line - About Lorie|website=www.lorieline.com|access-date=2017-11-15}}</ref> Line obtained a B.A. in Music, Piano Performance from the [[University of Nevada, Reno|University of Nevada]] in Reno. She married Tim Line in 1986 before moving to Minneapolis to accept a job as a pianist for Dayton's department stores. Line's musical career began to pick up speed as many Midwestern fans began to notice her talented piano skills while they shopped in these department stores.
Line has become one of the most published arrangers and composers in the last thirty years.<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=https://www.lorieline.com/about.php|title=Lorie Line - About Lorie|website=www.lorieline.com|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref> Since 1989, she has written and arranged music, published over 50 books of sheet music, recorded 50 CDs, and released 44 albums on her own [[independent label]]. She has sold over 6 million albums and continues to tour and perform about 60 to 80 concerts per year. Thousands of people listen to her Pandora Lorie Line radio station and her music "spins" nearly 2 million times every week. In addition to her general concerts, Line has performed for congressmen, governors, and two presidents. She has produced three television specials for PBS and won the [[Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award]] in 2002 in the entertainment category. Her story and home have been featured in hundreds of news articles and national magazines and her private costumes have been showcased in museums. In 2015, Line was inducted in the Minnesota Hall of Fame, joining ranks with artists such as [[Judy Garland]], [[Bob Dylan discography|Bob Dylan,]] and [[Prince (musician)|Prince]].<ref name="auto"/>
Line and her husband have lived on Lake Minnetonka in Minnesota for the past twenty years and become active gardeners; Line herself became a member of the Wayzata Garden Club fifteen years ago. They have two adult children and have raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for charities.<ref name="auto"/>
==Partial Discography==
A selection of Line's albums and music books, produced by her [[independent label]] Lorie Line Music, Inc. includes:

[[File:YingYaiShengLan.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A page from Ming dynasty woodcut printed edition of Yingya Shenglan by Ma Huan]] '''Ma Huan''' ({{zh|s=马欢|t=馬歡|p=Mǎ Huān}}, [[Xiao'erjing]]: {{lang|zh-Arab| ﻣَﺎ ﺧُﻮًا }}) (c. 1380–1460<ref name=ency>{{citation |contribution=Ma Huan |first=A.D.W. | last=Forbes |editor-first=C.E. |editor-last=Bosworth |isbn=90-04-07164-4 |title=The Encyclopaedia of Islam |publisher=E.J. Brill |year=1983 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=jJY3AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA849 | pages=849–850}}</ref>), courtesy name '''Zongdao''' ({{Zh|c=宗道|s=|t=|p=Zōngdào}}), pen name '''Mountain-woodcutter''' (會稽山樵), was a [[China|Chinese]] voyager and translator who accompanied Admiral [[Zheng He]] on three of his [[Treasure voyages|seven expeditions to the Western Oceans]]. Ma was a [[Muslim]] and was born in [[Zhejiang]]'s [[Kuaiji Commandery]], an area within the modern borders of [[Shaoxing]]. He knew several Classical Chinese and Buddhist texts. He learned Arabic to be able to translate.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jJY3AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA849&dq=hui+muslims+chinese+new+year&hl=en&ei=NCeOTc6qLpS80QHZ3aWjCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFsQ6AEwCTgK#v=onepage&q=hui%20muslims%20chinese%20new%20year&f=false|title=Encyclopedia of Islam, Volumes 1–5|author=Sir H. A. R. Gibb|year=|publisher=Brill Archive|location=|isbn=90-04-07164-4|page=849|pages=|accessdate=2011-03-26}}</ref>
In the 1413 expedition (the 4th), he visited [[Champa]], [[Java (island)|Java]], [[Sumatra]], [[Palembang]], [[Siam]], [[Kochi, India|Kochi]] and [[Ormus|Hormuz]].
In the 1421 expedition, he visited [[Malacca]], [[Sultanate of Deli|Aru]], [[Sumatra]], [[Trincomalee]], [[Ceylon]], Kochi, [[Kozhikode|Calicut]], [[Zufar]] and Hormuz.
In the 1431 expedition, he visited [[Bengal]], [[Chittagong]], [[Sonargaon]], [[Gauḍa (city)|Gaur]] and Calicut. From Calicut, he was sent by Eununch [[Hong Bao]] as emissary to [[Mecca]].
During his expeditions, Ma Huan took notes about the geography, politics, weather conditions, environment, economy, local customs, even method of punishment for criminals. Returned home on his first expedition, he began writing a book about his expedition, the first draft of which was ready around 1416. He expanded and modified his draft during later expeditions, the final version was ready around 1451. The title of his book was ''[[Yingya Shenglan]]'' (The Overall Survey of the Ocean's Shores).
During the [[Ming dynasty]] and [[Qing dynasty]], there were many printed and handcopied editions. The latest authentic text of a printed version was edited and annotated by historian {{ill|Feng Chengjun|zh|馮承鈞}}. A newer edition, based on Ming dynasty handcopied editions, was recently published by Ocean Publishing House in China.
An annotated English translation by [[J.V.G. Mills]] (1887–1987) was published by the [[Hakluyt Society]] in 1970,<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/stable/2053070 Book review by Jung-pang Lo]</ref> and reprinted in 1997 by The White Lotus Press in Bangkok. Mills's translation was based on the edition by Feng Cheng jun.
The ''Yingya Shenglan'' is considered by sinologists worldwide as a primary source for the history of Ming dynasty naval exploration, history of [[South East Asia]] and [[history of India]].
Some scholars who have done research work on Ma Huan are J.J.L. Duyvendak, F. Hirth, [[Paul Pelliot]], [[Feng Chengjun]], [[Xiang Da]], [[J.V.G. Mills]].

[[File:Matthew Ladner by Gage Skidmore.jpg|right|thumb|Ladner in April 2018]] '''Matthew Ladner''' (born September 1, 1967 in [[Port Arthur, Texas]]) is the Senior Advisor for Policy and Research at the [[Foundation for Excellence in Education]] (FEE).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.excelined.org/Pages/About_Us/Team.aspx |title=About Us - Team |publisher=Foundation for Excellence in Education |accessdate=2012-02-21}}</ref> Ladner focuses on various school choice issues including [[school voucher]]s, [[charter school]]s, race and [[special education]].
==Education== Ladner received his Bachelor of Arts Degree from the [[University of Texas at Austin]] in 1990. He received his master's degree in 1994 and his Doctorate in 1996, both from the [[University of Houston]].
==Career== Prior to working at FEE, Ladner was Vice President of Research for the Goldwater Institute, Vice President of Policy and Communications at Children First America and Director of State Projects at the [[Alliance for School Choice]]. In addition to his position as the Vice President of Research, Ladner was the Director for Economic Prosperity at Goldwater. Ladner is also a Friedman Fellow at [[EdChoice]],<ref name="Edchoice.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.EdChoice.org/about/ShowFellows.do |title=Fellows |publisher=The Friedman Foundation For Educational Choice |accessdate=2012-02-21}}</ref> and a Senior Fellow at the [[Texas Public Policy Foundation]]<ref name="texaspolicy1">{{cite web|url=http://www.texaspolicy.com/experts.php?auth_id=112 |title=Policy Expert - Matthew Ladner |publisher=Texas Public Policy Foundation |accessdate=2012-02-21}}</ref> and the Goldwater Institute.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goldwaterinstitute.org/people |title=It Takes a Team. |publisher=Goldwater Institute |accessdate=2012-02-21}}</ref>
Ladner has testified before various state legislatures and the U.S. [[House Committee on Education and the Workforce]] and the U.S. [[Commission on Civil Rights]]. Ladner's writing and work was featured in several newspapers across the United States including [[National Review Online]] and [[The New Republic]].
Currently{{when|date=March 2015}}, Ladner has a book in development with the [[American Legislative Exchange Council]] on [[K-12]] education.
==Selected writings== *{{cite web|last=Ladner|first=Matthew |url=http://goldwaterinstitute.org/article/new-millennium-schools-delivering-six-figure-teacher-salaries-return-outstanding-student |title=New Millennium Schools: Delivering Six-Figure Teacher Salaries in Return for Outstanding Student Learning Gains |publisher=Goldwater Institute |date=2009-04-28 |accessdate=2012-02-21}} *{{cite web|last=Lips|first=Dan|author2=Matthew Ladner |url=http://www.goldwaterinstitute.org/article/2577 |title=Demography Defeated: Florida's K-12 Reforms and Their Lessons for the Nation |publisher=Goldwater Institute |date=2008-09-30 |accessdate=2012-02-21}} *{{cite web|last=Ladner|first=Matthew |url=http://goldwaterinstitute.org/article/how-win-war-poverty-analysis-state-poverty-trends-0 |title=How to Win the War on Poverty: An Analysis of State Poverty Trends |publisher=Goldwater Institute |date=2006-11-14 |accessdate=2012-02-21}}

{{Expand Indonesian|Suku Dayak Meratus|date=July 2017}} {{distinguish|Ukit people}} {{infobox ethnic group |group = '''Meratus people'''
'''Dayak Meratus''' |image = [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Kleurenlithos getiteld Orang-Boekit uit de Afdeeling Amoentai en Dajaksche vrouw uit Longwai van haar werk huiswaarts keerend TMnr 5795-30.jpg|300px]] |caption = Lithography by [[Carl Bock (explorer)|Car Bock]] made in 1879 and 1880 about his experiences traveling in eastern and southern Borneo, from Kutai to Banjarmasin in "Orang Bukit from Afdeeling Amoentai" and "Dayak woman from Longwai" written by him. |population = 56,000 (est.2000) |popplace = '''{{flag|Indonesia}}:'''
[[South Kalimantan]] (35,383) |rels = [[Kaharingan]], [[Hinduism]] |langs = [[Bukit Malay]], [[Banjarese language|Banjarese]], and [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] |related = [[Banjar people|Banjar]], [[Dayak people|Dayak]], [[Ngaju people|Ngaju]] }} The '''Meratus Dayak''' inhabit the [[Meratus Mountains]] of [[South Kalimantan]], [[Indonesia]]. The [[Banjar people|Banjar]] Kuala people would refer the Meratus people as '''Urang Baiju''' or '''Dayak Baiju''', as they consider them to be the same as the [[Ngaju people]]. While the [[Banjar people|Banjar]] Hulu Sungai people would call the Meratus people as '''Urang Bukit''', '''Dayak Bukit''' or '''Dayak Buguet'''.{{cite book|author=|title=The Monthly Repository (And Review)|year=1822|publisher=Universitas Oxford|isbn=}}{{cite book|author=Johannes Jacobus Ras|title=[[Hikayat Banjar|Hikajat Bandjar]]: A Study In Malay Historiography|year=1966|publisher=Hans Ras|oclc=1207982}} ==Naming== A Meratus Dayak's name changes over the course of his or her life. Children have "body names" (''ngaran badan'') that are not usually used after adolescence. When they have children, men and women acquire [[teknonym]]s (''ngaran ba'anak''). For a man this name is ''Ma'' X or ''Pa'an'' X, where X is the name of one of his children, or sometimes another word. For a woman it is ''Induan'' X or ''Dun'' X, depending on which part of the Meratus area she lives in. Older men become ''Awat'' X (grandfather of X) and older women become ''Apih'' X.{{cite book|author=Anna Lowenhaupt Tsing|title=In the Realm of the Diamond Queen: Marginality in an Out-of-the-way Place|year=1993|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=0-6910-0051-4}} ==Language== Local Meratus Dayak dialects are closely related linguistically to both [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] (the national language), and to the [[Banjar language|Banjar]] language. Most Meratus Dayak can speak Banjar and Indonesian since government administrators conduct business in Indonesian and trade with the [[Banjar people]] is conducted in Banjar. ==Sub-ethnics== The Meratus people are divided into several sub-ethnics including:- * Dayak Pitap people * Dayak Alai people ** Dayak Labuhan people ** Dayak Atiran people ** Dayak Kiyu people ** Dayak Juhu people * Dayak Hantakan (Dayak Bukit) people * Dayak Labuan Amas people * Dayak Loksado (Dayak Amandit) people * Dayak Harakit (Dayak Tapin) people * Dayak Paramasan people * Dayak Kayu Tangi people * Dayak Bangkalaan people * Dayak Sampanahan people * Dayak Riam Adungan people * Dayak Bajuin people * Dayak Sembamban Baru people * and many more ==Culture== ===Dance=== * Gintur Dadas dance, a ritualistic dance practiced by the Dayak Meratus Halong people to summon ancestral spirits.{{cite web|url=http://kalsel.prokal.co/read/news/5824-inilah-tarian-khas-dayak-meratus-halong-tarian-memanggil-roh.html |title=Inilah Tarian Khas Dayak Meratus Halong, Tarian Memanggil Roh |author= |publisher=Pro Kalsel |date=13 October 2016 |accessdate=2016-11-05}} * Batandik, a dance performed to summon ancestral spirits during the Aruh Baharin ritual.{{cite web|url=http://nationalgeographic.co.id/berita/2015/11/tarian-mistik-dayak-balanghan/1 |title=Tarian Mistik Dayak Balanghan |author=Ahmad Fauzi |publisher=National Geographic Indonesia |date=27 November 2015 |accessdate=2016-11-05}} ===Rituals=== * Aruh Baharin, a ritual also practiced by the Buddhist majority Dayak Balanghan people to close the paddy farming season after the completion of harvesting the field. ==Economy== Meratus Dayak are primarily farmers, and rice is the main crop. [[Rice cultivation]] occurs in [[swidden]]s (cleared portions of the forest). Swiddens are usually cultivated for a few years, then the forest is allowed to regenerate when the farmers move to a different swidden location to farm. The farmers may return to a swidden, although there is usually at least 15 years between leaving and returning to a swidden.{{cite web|url=http://www.republika.co.id/berita/nasional/umum/13/11/02/mvn57k-menanam-padi-di-meratus-panen-hari-ini-untuk-kebutuhan-belasan-tahun-nanti |title=Menanam Padi di Meratus, Panen Hari Ini untuk Kebutuhan Belasan Tahun Nanti |author=Priyantono Oemar |publisher=Republika |date=2 November 2013 |accessdate=2016-11-05}} Meratus people also collect forest products and trade with Banjar at markets outside the mountains. In these transactions Banjar typically act as middle men between the Meratus and other traders. ==Social organization== Most Meratus live and farm in ''umbun'' which are also considered the primary [[social unit]]s among the Meratus Dayak. ''Umbun'' are founded by a man and a woman, usually a married couple, but sometimes also a brother and sister, a widow and her adult son, or other male-female pairs. ''Umbun'' also embrace a variety of dependents who have not yet founded their own ''umbun'', including children and recently married, disabled, and widowed adults. The founding pair is responsible for the ''umbun''.{{cite book|author=Victor T. King; William D. Wilder|title=The Modern Anthropology of South-East Asia: An Introduction|year=2003|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=0-4152-9751-6}} Some Meratus have also been moved into villages by government resettlement programs. The Meratus are classified as a "semi-nomadic" isolated tribe,{{cite web|url=http://www.handcraftedfilms.net/the-dayak-meratus/ |title=The Dayak Meratus |author=Tim Lewis |publisher=Handcrafted Films |date=4 March 2011 |accessdate=2016-11-05}} and are the target of government development programs as such. ==References== ==Further reading== * {{Citation | author=Anna Lowenhaupt Tsing | title=In The Realm Of The Diamond Queen | publication-date=1993 | publisher=[[Princeton University Press]] | isbn=978-0-691-00051-0 }} {{Ethnic groups in Indonesia}} {{Portal|Indonesia}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Indonesia]] [[Category:Hindu communities]] [[Category:Dayak people]]

{{Orphan|date=March 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} [[File:Nani at Aaha Kalyanam audio launch (cropped).jpg|thumb|200px|Nani at ''[[Aaha Kalyanam]]''{{'s}} audio launch in January 2014|alt=Nani looking away from the camera and greeting someone.]] [[Nani (actor)|Nani]] is an Indian film actor and producer who works predominantly in [[Telugu cinema]] and appears in a few [[Tamil language]] films. He made his acting debut with [[Mohan Krishna Indraganti]]{{'s}} 2008 comedy film ''[[Ashta Chamma]]'', an Indian adaptation of [[Oscar Wilde]]{{'s}} play ''[[The Importance of Being Earnest]]''.{{Cite web |url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2008/sep/01slid1.htm |title=Taking on Oscar Wilde! |last=Rajamani |first=Radhika |date=5 September 2008 |publisher=[[Rediff.com]] |archive-url=https://archive.is/20170715175152/http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2008/sep/01slid1.htm |archive-date=15 July 2017 |access-date=15 July 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }} After ''Ashta Chamma''{{'s}} commercial success,{{Cite web |url=http://www.rediff.com/money/report/tollywood-gives-case-study-to-isb/20090813.htm |title=Tollywood gives case study to ISB |last=Mohan |first=B Krishna |date=13 August 2009 |publisher=Rediff.com |archive-url=https://archive.is/20170721104429/http://www.rediff.com/money/report/tollywood-gives-case-study-to-isb/20090813.htm |archive-date=21 July 2017 |access-date=21 July 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Nani played the lead roles in three Telugu films in the next two years: ''[[Ride (2009 film)|Ride]]'' (2009), ''[[Snehituda...]]'' (2009) and ''[[Bheemili Kabaddi Jattu]]'' (2010). In 2011, Nani collaborated with [[B. V. Nandini Reddy]] on the romantic comedy film ''[[Ala Modalaindi]]'' which was profitable.{{Cite web |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-south-interview-with-b-v-nandini-reddy-on-jabardasth/20130219.htm |title='Jabardasth is a comedy carnival' |last=Rajamani |first=Radhika |date=19 February 2013 |publisher=Rediff.com |archive-url=https://archive.is/20170715175325/http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-south-interview-with-b-v-nandini-reddy-on-jabardasth/20130219.htm |archive-date=15 July 2017 |access-date=15 July 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The same year, he made his Tamil cinema debut with Anjana Ali Khan's ''[[Veppam]]'', a crime drama set in the backdrop of [[North Chennai]]. The following year, Nani collaborated with [[S. S. Rajamouli]] and [[Gautham Menon]] on the Telugu-Tamil bilingual ''[[Eega]]'' and the romance film ''[[Yeto Vellipoyindhi Manasu]]'' respectively. The former, which was about a murdered man reincarnating as a housefly and avenging his death, earned Nani an award in the Best Hero category at the [[Toronto After Dark Film Festival#2013|2013 Toronto After Dark Film Festival]].{{Cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Rajamoulis-Eega-continues-to-win-awards/articleshow/25166198.cms |title=Rajamouli’s Eega continues to win awards |date=3 November 2013 |work=The Times of India |access-date=5 April 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6gYzal3iz?url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Another-feather-in-Eegas-cap/articleshow/20760864.cms |archive-date=6 April 2016}} He received the [[Nandi Award for Best Actor]] for his performance in ''Yeto Vellipoyindhi Manasu''.{{Cite news |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/regional-movies/nandi-awards-here-s-the-complete-list-of-winners-for-2012-and-2013/story-98h1g3ETtYipb4qGVgcgaM.html |title=Nandi Awards: Here’s the complete list of winners for 2012 and 2013 |date=1 March 2017 |work=[[Hindustan Times]] |access-date=15 July 2017 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20170715180026/http://www.hindustantimes.com/regional-movies/nandi-awards-here-s-the-complete-list-of-winners-for-2012-and-2013/story-98h1g3ETtYipb4qGVgcgaM.html |archive-date=15 July 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Nani ventured into film production in 2013 as a co-producer for the film ''[[D for Dopidi]]''. He faced three box office failures in the upcoming years: ''[[Paisa (film)|Paisa]]'' (2013), ''[[Aaha Kalyanam]]'' (2014) and ''[[Janda Pai Kapiraju]]'' (2015). Nani termed it a "low phase" in his career and worked on the "planning of films and the timing of their release".{{Cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/movies/Nani-I-can%E2%80%99t-take-this-success-for-granted/article16925032.ece |title=Nani: I can’t take this success for granted |last=Dundoo |first=Sangeetha Devi |date=22 December 2016 |work=The Hindu |access-date=15 July 2017 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20170715165928/http://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/movies/Nani-I-can%E2%80%99t-take-this-success-for-granted/article16925032.ece |archive-date=15 July 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He then played the lead role in [[Nag Ashwin]]{{'s}} ''[[Yevade Subramanyam]]'' (2015), a film focusing on a businessperson's journey to the [[Himalayas]] seeking self exploration. Nani later starred in [[Maruthi Dasari]]{{'s}} comedy film ''[[Bhale Bhale Magadivoy]]'' (2015), in which he played an absent minded scientist easily prone to distraction. It was the actor's first [[blockbuster (entertainment)|blockbuster]] success,{{Cite news |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/regional/nani-tastes-first-blockbuster-success-with-bhale-bhale-magadivoy/ |title=Nani tastes first blockbuster success with ‘Bhale Bhale Magadivoy’ |date=25 October 2015 |work=[[The Indian Express]] |access-date=15 July 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151029073351/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/regional/nani-tastes-first-blockbuster-success-with-bhale-bhale-magadivoy/ |archive-date=29 October 2015 |agency=[[Indo-Asian News Service]]}} and earned him the [[Filmfare Critics Award for Best Actor – South|Critics Award for Best Actor - South]] at the [[63rd Filmfare Awards South]] ceremony.{{Cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Nani-wins-Critics-Award-for-Best-Actor-Male-at-63rd-Filmfare-Awards-South-2016/articleshow/52813442.cms |title=Nani wins Critics Award for Best Actor (Male) at 63rd Filmfare Awards South 2016 |date=16 January 2017 |work=The Times of India |access-date=15 July 2017 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20170715180541/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Nani-wins-Critics-Award-for-Best-Actor-Male-at-63rd-Filmfare-Awards-South-2016/articleshow/52813442.cms |archive-date=15 July 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }} With his subsequent releases, the profitable ventures ''[[Krishna Gaadi Veera Prema Gaadha]]'' (2016) and ''[[Gentleman (2016 film)|Gentleman]]'' (2016), he gained stardom in Telugu cinema.{{Cite news |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/telugu/2016/oct/08/tollywoods-mr-bankable-1525732--1.html |title=Nani: Tollywood's Mr Bankable |last=Yellapantula |first=Suhas |date=10 October 2016 |work=[[The New Indian Express]] |access-date=15 July 2017 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20170715172603/http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/telugu/2016/oct/08/tollywoods-mr-bankable-1525732--1.html |archive-date=15 July 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Nani later played the lead in the commercially successful Telugu films ''[[Majnu (2016 film)|Majnu]]'' (2016), ''[[Nenu Local]]'' (2017) and ''[[Ninnu Kori]]'' (2017).{{Cite magazine |date=10 October 2016 |title=Ninnu Kori: Nani's film rakes in Rs 25 crore in its opening weekend |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/ninnu-kori-box-office-collection-nani-niveda-thomas-aadhi/1/998288.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20170715180941/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/ninnu-kori-box-office-collection-nani-niveda-thomas-aadhi/1/998288.html |archive-date=15 July 2017 |access-date=15 {{BLP sources|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox person |name = Lady Bracewell-Smith |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Nina Kakkar |birth_place = [[New Delhi]], [[India]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|11|14|df=yes}} |residence = |nationality = |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = |education = |alma_mater = |employer = |occupation = |years_active = 1995–present |home_town = |title = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |opponents = |boards = |religion = |spouse = {{marriage|[[Charles Bracewell-Smith]] |1996|}} |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = |callsign = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }}
''' Nina, Lady Bracewell-Smith''' (born 14 November 1955) is an Indian-born, businesswoman who has since March 2013 been based in Monaco. She was a major shareholder and former [[non-executive director]] of the [[Premier League]] football club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.arsenal.com/the-club/corporate-info/the-arsenal-board | title=The Arsenal Board | work=Arsenal.com }}</ref><ref>[http://www.burkes-peerage.net/sites/Contents/book/UK/FHP/Peerage/fhp-SMITHOFKEIGHLEY.asp?&string1=bracewell&string2=smith&BookType=Peerage&Region=UK#hit-1 Burke's Peerage] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150609104842/http://www.burkes-peerage.net/sites/Contents/book/UK/FHP/Peerage/fhp-SMITHOFKEIGHLEY.asp?&string1=bracewell&string2=smith&BookType=Peerage&Region=UK#hit-1 |date=June 9, 2015 }}</ref>
==Background== Born '''Nina Kakkar''' in [[Bonn]], she is the daughter of an [[Foreign relations of India|Indian diplomat]].<ref> {{cite news | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/premiership/arsenal/article1680369.ece | title=Aristocrat has no desire to part with family heirloom | publisher=Times Online|date=20 April 2007 | location=London | first=Tom | last=Dart | accessdate=20 May 2010}}</ref> In 1996 she married [[Charles Bracewell-Smith|Sir Charles Bracewell-Smith, 4th Baronet]] (of [[Keighley]] in the [[County of Yorkshire]]) at Westminster Register Office. Her husband is the younger son of the former Arsenal director [[George Bracewell Smith|Sir George Bracewell-Smith, 2nd Baronet]] , who was on the Arsenal board of directors from May 1953 to September 1976. Sir George was in turn the son of the former Arsenal director [[Bracewell Smith|Sir Bracewell Smith, 1st Baronet]], who was chairman from 1948 to 1962.
==Arsenal FC== Lady Bracewell-Smith's share in [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] comes from the estate of Sir Bracewell Smith, which was split among his grandchildren, Sir Charles Bracewell-Smith, [[Clive Carr]], [[Richard Carr (businessman)|Richard Carr]] and Sarah Carr, now Lady Phipps-Bagge.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2007/04/19/sfnfro19.xml |title =Arsenal crisis as Dein is ousted from board|publisher=Daily Telegraph|date=19 April 2007 | location=London | first=David | last=Bond | accessdate=20 May 2010}}</ref> Sir Charles Bracewell-Smith transferred ownership of his shares to his wife, Lady Bracewell-Smith, and she was made a non-executive director of Arsenal in 2005; her appointment increased the membership of Arsenal's Board of Directors to ten.
As of September 2007, Lady Bracewell-Smith owned a 15.9% stake in the club and was the third largest shareholder in the club following [[Danny Fiszman]], with 24.11%, and Red and White Holdings, which is co-owned by [[Farhad Moshiri (businessman)|Farhad Moshiri]] and [[Alisher Usmanov]], which owns 24.0% of the equity. In April 2007, she joined with the other board members, her husband’s cousins, as well as Danny Fiszman and the chairman, [[Peter Hill-Wood]], in resisting a take-over by Usmanov, which was believed to have the support of former vice-chairman [[David Dein]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/sport/football.html?in_article_id=449619&in_page_id=1779 | title= Dynasty v Dein in battle for the board|publisher=Mail Online|date=19 April 2007}}</ref> On 17 December 2008 Arsenal Holdings PLC made this announcement: "Lady Nina Bracewell-Smith will be leaving the Boards of the Company and the Club with immediate effect."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/arsenal-holdings-plc-board-restructuring | title= Club announce board re-shuffle|publisher=Arsenal FC|date=17 December 2008 }}</ref>
On 11 April 2011, she sold her Arsenal shares amounting to 15.9% of club's stake to [[Stan Kroenke]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.plus-sx.com/newsItem.html?newsId=1155049 | title=Arsenal investor Lady Bracewell-Smith 'sell shares' | work=Plus-sx|date=11 April 2011}}</ref>
On 1 March 2012, she was appointed [http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/bracewell-smith-named-honorary-vice-president Honorary Vice-President of the Club].
==Other business interests== Lady Bracewell-Smith was also formerly a director of the Park Lane [[Sheraton Hotel]]. The Bracewell-Smith family has strong connections to hotels having previously owned the [[The Ritz London Hotel|Ritz Hotel]] in London, which they sold in 1976, together with a large share of the [[Paris Ritz]]; they also held the majority of the shares in the [[Park Lane Hotel]] (built by Sir Bracewell Smith in 1920) until its £44m sale in 1996.<ref name="SundayTimes">{{cite news | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/richlist/person/0,,43853,00.html | title=Sunday Times Rich List 2006 - Lady Nina Bracewell-Smith and Family | work=The Sunday Times | location=London | accessdate=20 May 2010}}</ref>
She and her husband were ranked 657th in the [[Sunday Times Rich List 2009]] <ref>[http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/specials/rich_list/rich_list_2009/article6133237.ece Lady Nina Bracewell-Smith and family] Times Online, 26 April 2009</ref> with an estimated family fortune of £85m.<ref name="SundayTimes"/> She is also 44th on ''The Sunday Times'' [[British Asian|UK Asian]] rich list,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://extras.timesonline.co.uk/pdfs/strlasians.pdf | title=Britain's Richest Asians | work=The Sunday Times | location=London | accessdate=20 May 2010}}</ref> 72nd on the women list and is in the European Rich List.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.revs.org/blog/?p=29 | title=Richest People in Europe | work=Revs.org }}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Omar Sakr | image = File:Omar_Sakr_in_the_opening_ceremony_of_Pirámide_Academy_in_Nigeria.jpg | caption = Sakr (far left) in the opening ceremony of his academy in Nigeria. | birth_name = Omar Hassan Sakr | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1996|01|08|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Giza]], Egypt | nationality = Egyptian | occupation = [[Sports agent|Football agent]] | years_active = 1996–present }} '''Omar Sakr'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://omarsakr.me/|title=Omar Sakr|website=omarsakr.me}}</ref> (born 8 January 1996) is a Giza based football agent<ref>https://sport.elwatannews.com/ar/1/1/175134</ref> who is working as an agent for Piramide sport management. He is considered the youngest football agent in the Middle East. He founded his own football academy at his hometown [[Giza]] which is called Pirámide Academy.
== Early career == Omar was a passionate football player before starting his career as a football agent. He was just a young, promising Egyptian talent trying to prove himself as a player in Europe, but instead, he returned from Europe to start his career as a football agent and sports entrepreneur.
== Pirámide Academy == On 12 December 2016, he opened a football academy known as Pirámide (English: Pyramids), the only football academy in Egypt that provides marketing for the players in the domestic clubs all over the world free of charge. The academy also provides diplomas for refereeing and coaching for individuals. It aims to discover and help Egyptian football talents.
== Extremadura UD tryouts == On 10 July 2017, Pirámide Academy field hosted a tryout for [[Extremadura UD]], a Spanish football team. It was the first foreign football tryouts to happen in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.egypttoday.com/Article/8/35447/Omar-Sakr-Egyptian-success-story-in-Europe|title=Omar Sakr, Egyptian success story in Europe - Egypt Today|website=www.egypttoday.com}}</ref>

{{Infobox Officeholder |name = Ron Prosor |honorific-prefix = [[Excellency|His Excellency]] |image = RONPROSOR.PNG |office = [[Permanent Representative of Israel to the United Nations]] |term_start = 8 June 2011 |term_end = 14 October 2015 |president = [[Shimon Peres]]
[[Reuven Rivlin]] |primeminister = [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] |predecessor = [[Meron Reuben]] |successor = [[Danny Danon]] |office2 = [[List of Israeli ambassadors to the United Kingdom|15th Israeli Ambassador to the United Kingdom]] |term_start2 = 2007 |term_end2 = 2011 |president2 = [[Shimon Peres]] |primeminister2 = [[Ehud Olmert]]
[[Benjamin Netanyahu]] |predecessor2 = [[Zvi Heifetz]] |successor2 = [[Daniel Taub]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|10|11|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Kfar Saba]], [[Israel]] |death_date = |death_place = | occupation = Diplomat, writer, columnist |alma_mater = [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] |religion = [[Judaism]]}} '''Ron Prosor''' ({{lang-he|רון פרושאור}}; born 11 October 1958){{cite web|author=Jenni Frazer|url=http://www.thejc.com/lifestyle/lifestyle-features/49486/interview-ron-prosor|title=Interview: Ron Proser|publisher=The Jewish Chronicle Online |date=26 May 2011|accessdate=16 November 2012}}{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/RonProsor/info |title=Ron Prosor – רון פרושאור – About |publisher=Facebook |date=1958-10-11 |accessdate=2015-08-12}} is an [[Israel]]i diplomat, writer, and columnist. He is the Head of the [https://www.idc.ac.il/en/research/aei/pages/main.aspx Abba Eban Institute for International Diplomacy] in IDC Herzliya Lauder School of Government, Diplomacy & Strategy since. He served as Israel's Permanent Representative to the [[United Nations]] from 2011 to 2015. He has previously served as Israel's Ambassador to the [[United Kingdom]], Director-General of Israel's Foreign Ministry and political consul at the Israeli embassy in Washington.[http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/netanyahu-gives-in-to-lieberman-names-permanent-envoy-to-un-1.343082 Netanyahu names permanent envoy to UN], haaretz.com; accessed August 12, 2015. ==Biography== Born in October 11th 1958 in Kfar Saba (Israel). Prosor is a graduate of the IDF Battalion Commanders. As an officer in the Artillery Division of the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]], Prosor attained the rank of [[Major]] and he is a graduate of the IDF Battalion Commanders. He holds a Bachelor and a Masters degree in Political Science from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], graduating with distinction. Prosor and his wife Hadas have three children – Lior, Tomer and Oren – and two grandchildren, Amit and Daniel.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} ==Diplomatic career and previous postings== With almost three decades of experience at the [[Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs]], Prosor has carved out an international reputation as one of Israel’s most distinguished diplomats. His overseas service also includes roles in Washington, Bonn, and London. In 1986, he joined the staff of the Foreign Ministry and began fulfilling his duties in Israel's diplomatic missions throughout the world. During his service as a spokesman for the embassy in Bonn, he was one of the first Israeli representatives to establish ties with East Germany and, after its unification with West Germany, he worked to establish relations with the new federal states in its territory. He later served as the spokesman for the Israeli embassy in London. He became a political advisor to the Israeli Embassy in Washington (1998–2002) and participated in the Israeli delegation to the negotiations prior to the signing of the Wye Agreement and took part in the Camp David delegation in 2000. In the headquarters of the Foreign Ministry, he worked in the Western European Division, served as the spokesman for the ministry and served as the Head of the Foreign Ministry's diplomatic staff, as well as the Deputy Director-General of the Foreign Ministry. Between 2004 and 2007 Prosor served as the Director General of the [[Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs]], overseeing the work of the Foreign Ministry during the [[disengagement from Gaza]] in 2005. From 2007 and 2011, he served as [[List of Israeli ambassadors to the United Kingdom|Israel’s Ambassador to the United Kingdom]], where he earned plaudits for his articulate and forthright defense of Israel's position, publishing numerous articles throughout the British press and appearing on television outlets including the [[BBC]] and [[Sky News]]. He also addressed a wide range of audiences throughout the country, including universities and think tanks.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} Finally, Prosor served as [[Permanent Representative of Israel to the United Nations|Israel's Permanent Representative]] to the [[United Nations]] from 2011 to 2015. ==Permanent Representative to the United Nations== [[File:Ambassador Prosor at the General Assembly.PNG|thumb|Ambassador Prosor gives a speech at the UN General Assembly.]]As Israel’s 16th Ambassador to the UN, Prosor has held a series of notable positions, including Vice President of the General Assembly (June 8th 2012) and Chair of the United Nations Human Rights Committee.{{cite web|url=http://embassies.gov.il/un/AboutTheEmbassy/Pages/Ambassador-Ron-Prosor.aspx |title=Ambassador Ron Prosor |publisher=Embassies.gov.il |date=2012-03-26 |accessdate=2015-08-12}} Prosor called for the first-ever General Assembly session on Antisemitism and oversaw the adoption of two landmark resolutions on entrepreneurship and agriculture that passed with an overwhelming majority.{{cite web|url=http://www.herzliyaconference.org/eng/?CategoryID=542 |title=List of Speakers |publisher=Herzliyaconference.org |date= |accessdate=2015-08-12}} [[File:Prosor2.jpg|thumb|Ambassador Prosor Presents his credentials to UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon]] Since becoming Israel’s Permanent Representative to the [[United Nations]], Prosor has continued to be an outspoken proponent for the State of Israel.[http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000656396 Ron Prosor profile], globes.co.il; accessed 12 August 2015. A prolific writer and commentator, Prosor has published in leading international publications, including ''The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, Newsweek and more''."Tolerating Hamas Invites a Mideast War", ''The Wall Street Journal''; retrieved 8 July 2015.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/7474344/Commentary-The-response-to-Israels-announcement-is-disproportionate.html "The response to Israel's announcement is disproportionate"], telegraph.co.uk; accessed 2 August 2015. ==Foreign policy positions== Prosor is known as an outspoken diplomat and delivers speeches on a wide range of topics. He frequently publishes articles on a variety of international publications on Israel’s domestic policy and international status. He often attacks Hamas and seeks to raise awareness among the international community on the necessity to stop funding Hamas terrorist activities. In summer 2014, during the most recent conflict in Gaza, Prosor publicly accused Qatar of supporting terrorism. ===Israeli domestic policy=== He faults the Palestinian Authority for being unwilling to negotiate with Israel,{{cite web|url=http://mfa.gov.il/MFA/InternatlOrgs/Speeches/Pages/Amb-Prosor-addresses-UNGA-on-the-Question-of-Palestine-24-Nov-2014.aspx |title=Amb Prosor addresses UNGA on the Question of Palestine 24 Nov 2014 |publisher=Mfa.gov.il |date=2014-11-24 |accessdate=2015-08-12}} as well as the European states which unilaterally recognized a Palestinian state, thus sending the message that "the Palestinian Authority can sit in a government with terrorists and incite violence against Israel without paying any price." Moreover, Prosor defends a two-state solution{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/israel-un-ambassador-ron-prosor-speech-text/1555643.html |title=Full text of Israeli Amb. Ron Prosor's speech to the UN General Assembly |publisher=Voanews.com |date=2012-11-29 |accessdate=2015-08-12}} and calls on the international community to "encourage the Palestinians to enter into direct negotiations without preconditions in order to achieve a historical peace process in which a demilitarized Palestinian state will recognizes the Jewish state." ===Recognition of Israel=== On several occasions, Prosor has framed the recognition of Israel's statehood as an existential right for Israel and the Jewish people.{{cite web|author=Ron Prosor |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/apr/20/taboo-arabs-israel-jewish-character |title=A taboo that harms Arabs too |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2015-08-12}} According to Prosor, failing to recognize Israel is the greatest obstacle to peace in the region. Therefore, he stressed the necessity for Arab states and the Palestinian Authority to recognize Israel. In his speech to the UN General Assembly in November 2014, Prosor accused the international community of fueling the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by not understanding the history of the region. He also blamed the Arab States for their wars against Israel, and concluded his address by acknowledging the necessity for the international community to choose between recognizing Israel as the nation-state of the Jewish people or allowing Palestine to deny Israel’s rightful claim to its land. In an op-ed published in the ''New York Times'' in March 2015, Prosor faulted the UN for singling out Israel on a variety of issues, for example, human rights, while not addressing more oppressive regimes.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/01/opinion/united-in-ignominy.html?_r=0|title=United in Ignominy|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2015-08-12}} He indeed accused the UN of tolerating "repressive regimes that violate human rights and undermine international security" to control the organization. ===Palestine and Hamas=== Prosor condemns Hamas’ brutal practices – from jailing women who remove their veils, to throwing political opponents from buildings, and promoting genocide in school and on TV, while pretending to be "moderate" and "reforming."{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/personal-view/6088655/Hamas-is-leading-Palestine-down-the-road-of-carnage.html |title=Hamas is leading Palestine down the road of carnage |publisher=Telegraph |date= |accessdate=2015-08-12}} He also complains about weapons smuggling over the Egyptian border, as well as other black market items. Each of his commentaries lambastes Hamas for its use of rocket attacks and small-arms fire, which frequently kill civilians and destroy homes and buildings. In an article that appeared on ''The Telegraph'' in 2009, Prosor emphasized the failure of the international community to counter Hamas’ fundamentalism and violence against both Palestinians and Israelis. He further argued that extremist regimes like Hamas pose a threat to the prosperity and stability of the Middle East. ===Qatari financing and support of terrorism=== Interviewed in July 2014 by CBS reporter Pamela Falk on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in Gaza, Prosor claimed that Hamas’ "terror tunnels" were funded by Qatari money, and stressed the necessity to demilitarize the military infrastructure of Hamas towards the reconstruction of Gaza.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UcFLIUHiQb4 |title=Israel's UN ambassador shares roadblocks to halting hostilities with Hamas |publisher=YouTube |date=2014-07-28 |accessdate=2015-08-12}} Prosor compared Qatar’s support for Hamas to Iranian military support of terrorism against Israel and more generally in the Middle East. He further noted that Qatar’s and Egypt's support for Hamas and the Muslim Brotherhood stood in contrast to other Arab nations and deepened cleavages in the region. Furthermore, in his "Club Med for Terrorists" op-ed published in August 2014 in the ''New York Times'' entitled, "Club Med for Terrorists" Prosor alleged that Qatar sought to improve its global image by funding prominent foreign universities in Doha and hosting the 2022 World Cup while simultaneously supporting Hamas, al-Qaeda, and the Muslim Brotherhood.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/25/opinion/qatar-club-med-for-terrorists.html?_r=0|title=Qatar Club Med for Terrorists|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2015-08-12}} He claimed that "hundreds of millions of dollars" of Qatari funds "funneled" to Gaza have ended up in the hands of Hamas, and noted that Qatar "harbors leading Islamist radicals," including Sheikh [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] (spiritual leader of the Muslim Brotherhood), Abdul Rahman Omeir al-Naimi (designated by the US as a terrorist financier of al-Qaeda), and Khaled Meshal (the leader of Hamas). In particular, Prosor denounced Qatar’s intention to play "a starring role in any cease-fire agreement between Hamas and Israel". In fact, the diplomat argued that Qatar threatened to expel Khaled Meshal – whose uncompromising refusal to recognize Israel has been an obstacle to reaching a peace deal – if "Hamas accepted Egyptian proposals for a long-term cease-fire in Gaza."{{cite web|author=Jack Khoury |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/1.611625 |title=Report: Qatar Threatened to Expel Meshal if He Agreed to Cairo Truce Draft Diplomacy and Defense Haaretz Daily Newspaper Israel News |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=2014-08-20 |accessdate=2015-08-12}} Prosor concluded the op-ed by calling on Western nations to confront Qatar and demand that it stops financing Hamas. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.israel-un.org/ Permanent Mission of Israel to the United Nations] * [https://www.facebook.com/RonProsor Ron Prosor on Facebook] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130520093216/https://www.facebook.com/IsraelatUN Israel in the UN on Facebook] * [https://twitter.com/#!/IsraelinUN Israel in the UN on Twitter] * "[http://www.newsweek.com/israel-welcomes-donald-trump-netanyahu-superpower-era-557653 Israel Welcomes the Return of the U.S. Superpower]", [[Newsweek]], Feb 16, 2017. * "[https://www.hudson.org/research/13388-how-congress-can-boost-haley-at-the-u-n How Congress Can Boost Haley at the U.N]", [[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]], Feb 27, 2017. * "[http://www.newsweek.com/antonio-guterres-nikki-haley-democraciesun-572020 Democracies Must Stand Up To End U.N. Farce]", [[Newsweek]], Mar 22, 2017. * [https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4954660,00.html UNESCO trying to impose a fake history], [[Ynet|YNET]] News, Apr 29, 2017. * "[https://www.hudson.org/research/13646-there-s-still-time-to-avert-war-in-lebanon There’s Still Time to Avert War in Lebanon]", [[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]], May 29, 2017. * "[http://www.newsweek.com/strong-egypt-trump-knows-strong-middle-east-647746 A Strong Egypt Is a Strong Middle East]", [[Newsweek]], Aug 8, 2017. * "[https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/24/opinion/trump-kurdish-independence.html Trump Should Bet on Kurdish Independence]", [[New York Times]], Sep. 24, 2017. * "[https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5022375,00.html Israel must not let Arab states hijack UNESCO]", [[Ynet|YNET]] News, Sep 29, 2017. {{Permanent Representatives of Israel to the United Nations}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Prosor, Ron}} [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Israel to the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Ashkenazi Jews]] [[Category:Hebrew University of Jerusalem alumni]] [[Category:Hudson Institute]] [[Category:Israeli columnists]] [[Category:Israeli diplomats]] [[Category:Israeli political writers]] [[Category:Jewish Israeli politicians]] [[Category:Jewish writers]] [[Category:People from Jerusalem]] [[Category:Political commentators]] [[Category:Writers on the Middle East]] [[Category:Writers on Zionism]]

{{unreferenced|date=September 2013}} '''Salama Hijazi ''' (الشيخ سلامة حجازي), born 1852, died October 4, 1917 was an Egyptian singer. He was a pioneer of [[musical theatre]] in [[Egypt]] in the first half of the 20th century.
Born Salama Ibrahim Hijazi, he was known as Sheikh Salama. In 1852 in Shiben El Kom, El Mnofia, he recited the [[Qur'an]], after memorising the entire book.
Many famous singers in Egypt, such as Munira Mahdia and [[Mohamed Abdel Wahab]], have sung his music. He promoted [[Sayed Darwish]], who considered him an inspiration.
[[Iskandar Farah]] and Salama founded a theater company in 1891.
In 1914, with [[George Abiad]], he helped in the formation of a new group and they worked together until his death, despite being paralyzed at the end of his days he continued to appear on stage. He has been credited with many forms of musical theatre and operetta music.
== Notable work == *With Iskandar Farah: **African **Talimak **Ataiwaq **King of the reservoirs. *Solo: **[[Saladin]] *With George Abiad: **Egypt **The Heart of a Woman **[[Al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah]] **To the Homeland **Criminal Innocent

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Shea Gopaul | image = Shea Gopaul.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Shea Gopaul in 2016 | order = | office = Executive Director of the [[Global Apprenticeship Network]] }} '''Shea Gopaul''' is the Founder and Executive Director of the [[Global Apprenticeship Network]], a coalition of companies and organizations addressing the skills mismatch and youth unemployment crisis since 2013.
==Education== Shea Gopaul is an [[Institute for the Study of Labor]] Policy Fellow and a recipient of an Honorary Doctorate in Humane Letters<ref>{{cite web|title=Shea Gopaul, Policy Fellow|url=http://www.iza.org/en/webcontent/personnel/photos/index_html?key=22561|website=Institute for the Study of Labor|publisher=IZA}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018}}</ref>
==Career==
With over 20 years of experience within the [[United Nations]] system,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Commella|first1=Nancy|title=Alumna Shea Gopaul now on world stage at United Nations|url=http://www.pointpark.edu/About/AdminDepts/MarketingandCommunications/ThePoint/currentfeatures/globalperformance3|website=Point Park University|publisher=Point Park University}}</ref> Gopaul has worked in Director positions at the [[United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]] (OCHA), the World Health Organization and the International Labour Organization in the areas of humanitarian affairs, youth employment and administration, before establishing the GAN.
Shea Gopaul is also a member of the B20 Employment Taskforce,<ref>{{cite web|title=Documents|url=https://www.b20germany.org/documents/|website=B20 Germany 2017}}</ref> a Sherpa of the European Pact for Youth within CSR Europe<ref>{{cite web|title=The European Pact for Youth|url=http://www.csreurope.org/sites/default/files/publications/European_Pact_for_Youth.pdf|website=CSR Europe}}</ref> and an International Gender Champion,<ref>{{cite web|title=International Gender Champions|url=http://genderchampions.com/shea-gopaul/|website=International Gender Champions}}</ref> a network for [[gender equality]].
An accomplished classical ballet dancer,<ref>{{cite journal|title=An experiment in goodwill|journal=The Rotarian|date=March 1980|url=https://books.google.ch/books?id=LzQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA30&lpg=PA30&dq=shea+gopaul&source=bl&ots=vmTnooUm-C&sig=XWBCPnKGUaWWKnC4YH93blEoJy0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiYs56C7K_QAhXEVxQKHbJuBQcQ6AEIPjAJ#v=onepage&q=shea%20gopaul&f=false}}</ref> she remains active in the art world and is on the Board of Directors of Battery Dance Company in New York, which uses dance to foster intercultural exchange and understanding.<ref>{{cite web|title=Board and Advisors|url=http://batterydance.org/board-and-advisors/|website=Battery Dance Company}}</ref>
===Publication===
In early 2013, Shea Gopaul led and authored an [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO) feasibility study to gather information from businesses about their [[apprenticeship]] programs and to seek their views on how an international business network on apprenticeships could add value for them. In collaboration with the [[International Organisation of Employers]] (IOE) and members of the [[World Economic Forum]]’s Global Agenda Council on Youth Unemployment, the feasibility study collected information from multi-stakeholders on country and company apprenticeship practices; and, explored the interest and eventual commitment of companies to join forces to promote apprenticeship through a [[Global Apprenticeships Network]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Feasibility Study for a Global Business Network on Apprenticeship|url=http://digitalcommons.ilr.cornell.edu/intl/293/|website=Cornell University}}</ref> Shea Gopaul has coauthored several articles on apprenticeships<ref>Can apprenticeships save young people from the threat of AI? Available at: https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2018/01/apprenticeships-young-people-artificial-intelligence/ </ref>, jobs<ref>Jobs Now! Learning From The Swiss Apprenticeship Model. Available at: https://www.forbes.com/sites/nicholaswyman/2017/10/20/jobs-now-learning-from-the-swiss-apprenticeship-model/#3edba2696b54</ref>,and other reskilling programs.<ref>Education and Re-skilling in the Age of AI. Available at: https://www.uscib.org/education-and-re-skilling-in-the-age-of-ai/</ref> She has been a regular voice on youth training at Davos and other B20 programs.
==References== {{reflist|33em}}
